summary: This document is a chain of internal email correspondence from May 2021 among FBI personnel and possibly others, discussing the scheduling of interviews with victims of Jeffrey Epstein and the potential relevance of these interviews to an investigation concerning Leon Black. The emails focus on logistical planning, availability, and the strategic value of victim testimony.

persons.name: Leon Black
persons.context: Mentioned as the subject of potential follow-up investigations based on interviews with Epstein victims. The emails discuss whether victim interviews contain information relevant to him.

persons.name: Jeanne
persons.context: Identified as an attorney representing a victim (referred to as 'her'). The FBI correspondent speaks with her to schedule an interview for her client.

persons.name: C-20
persons.context: An FBI agent or personnel member who wants to sit in on a victim interview but is described as 'totally swamped,' making scheduling difficult.

connections.description: The FBI correspondence questions whether interviews with Epstein victims contain information that would be relevant to an investigation concerning Leon Black.
Jeanne is identified as the attorney for a victim, coordinating the interview schedule with the FBI.
C-20, an FBI agent, intends to participate in the interview of a victim as part of the investigation.

events.title: Scheduled Victim Interview
events.description: An interview with a victim of Jeffrey Epstein, coordinated through her attorney Jeanne, was scheduled to take place at an FBI conference room. An interpreter was considered.

locations: Conference room at an unspecified FBI location (referred to with a redacted identifier)
keyFacts: The FBI was actively scheduling and conducting interviews with victims of Jeffrey Epstein as late as May 2021.
The investigative focus included assessing whether victim testimony contained information relevant to financier Leon Black.
Logistical details such as securing a conference room, arranging for an interpreter, and coordinating with victims' attorneys (like Jeanne) were part of the FBI's process.
The correspondence indicates internal deliberation about the value of opening or pursuing certain investigative leads based on victim impressions.
The document is a chain of emails showing routine investigative coordination, with several sender/recipient email addresses redacted.
